quoteLast: I say ‘should have occurred’, because observations have shown that high tide sometimes occurs a few minutes earlier or later than the time predicted in the Admiralty _Tide Tables_.[3232] Therefore, _accepting the general rule laid down by Admiral Beechey and Surveyor Calver_,[3233] the stream off the Dover cliffs would have turned to the west some time between 10.21 and 11.9 a.m., and again to the east at 5.24 p.m.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: [2833] On the day of Caesar’s first landing in Britain high water at Dover was about
quoteLast: (see pp. 610-1, _infra_); and when he was approaching the British coast in 54 B.C., the tide turned south-westward about ten miles east of Deal soon after daybreak, which was about 3.15 a.m. See pp. 655-9, _infra_.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: Thus, taking the August full moon of the years 1883-1900, the time of high tide at Folkestone varied between 11.5 a.m. in 1896 and 10.17 a.m. in 1900; while the time of high tide of the fifth day before the full moon varied between
quoteLast: in 1893 and 4.46 a.m. in 1898; and high tide on the morning of August 19, 1896, was 90 minutes later than high tide on the morning of August 18, not 50 minutes, as it should have been according to Cardwell. If he had said that ‘_on the average_ each successive tide is later by twenty-five minutes than the one which had preceded it’, he would have told the truth.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: On the 26th of August, 55 B.C., the Greenwich mean time of high water at Dover was
quoteLast: ; on the 27th, 7.42 a.m.; and on the 28th, 8.44 a.m.[2996] Thus it turns out that on the day of Caesar’s landing high water did not occur at all early. This fact, however, will not sustain the theory of Airy and Lewin.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: This fact, however, will not sustain the theory of Airy and Lewin. Since high water at Dover on the 26th of August occurred at
quoteLast: , and since the tidal stream, according to one of Calver’s observations, turned 3 hours, 40 minutes after high water, the stream may have turned westward at 10.1 a.m. Assuming that the duration of the westward stream was 5 hours, 53 minutes--the same as that recorded on one occasion by Calver--the stream would have ceased at 3.54 p.m. But Calver’s observations were made ‘in comparatively still weather’;[2997] and, to quote Admiral Beechey, ‘winds greatly affect the time of turn of the stream.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: This resolution Mr. Benton, of Missouri, in February, 1835, brought forward a motion to expunge from the journals of the senate; but that body, on the third of March, by a vote of
quoteLast: , refused to sustain the motion. Mr. Benton, however, continued to agitate the subject, and, at the session of 1836–7, the majority of the senate having been changed in favor of president Jackson, an expunging resolution was offered by Mr. Benton, and, after an exciting debate, carried.
title:
A Biography of Henry Clay, the Senator from Kentucky
Containing Also, a Complete Report of All His Speeches; Selections From His Private Correspondence; Eulogies in the Senate and House; and a Poem, by George D. Prentice, Esq.
author: Mallory, Daniel, -1854? [Compiler]

quoteFirst: So distinct was this object, and so real the danger, that Perceval asked Parliament[276] to restrict the consumption of grain in the distilleries in order to countervail the loss of American wheat and avert a famine. The price of wheat had risen from
quoteLast: ty-two shillings a quarter, and every farmer hoped for a rise above one hundred shillings, as in 1795 and 1800. Disorders occurred; lives were lost; the embargo, as a coercive measure, pressed severely on British society; and Madison, with such a weapon in his hand, could not require Perceval to perceive the impropriety of inviting a friendly people to violate their own laws.
title: History of the United States of America, Volume 4 (of 9)
author: Adams, Henry, 1838-1918

quoteFirst: "I mean," answered Monk, briskly, "that the photograph itself is all right, and the person who is in the photograph is Evelina Reierson.
